slides.title: Welcome to GitLab
slides.content:
# Introduction to GitLab ğŸ¦Š

GitLab is a complete **DevOps platform** delivered as a single application.

## What you'll learn:
- **Pipelines** - Automated CI/CD workflows
- **Merge Requests** - Code review and collaboration
- **Wikis** - Project documentation

> ğŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** GitLab was started in 2011 by a Ukrainian developer and now powers millions of projects worldwide!

## GitLab vs GitHub

| Feature | GitLab | GitHub |
|---------|--------|--------|
| CI/CD | Built-in | Actions (separate) |
| Self-hosting | Free CE edition | Enterprise only |
| Issue boards | Included | Limited |
| DevOps stages | All integrated | Third-party tools |

## Why Choose GitLab?

- ğŸ”„ **All-in-One Platform** - From planning to monitoring
- ğŸ  **Self-Hosted Option** - Full control over your data
- ğŸ†“ **Generous Free Tier** - 400 CI/CD minutes/month
- ğŸ” **Security First** - Built-in security scanning

Let's explore GitLab!

slides.title: GitLab CI/CD Overview
slides.content:
# GitLab CI/CD Pipelines ğŸ”„

GitLab CI/CD is a powerful tool for **automating** your software delivery process.

## The Pipeline Concept


## Key Components

| Component | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Pipeline** | Collection of jobs organized in stages |
| **Stage** | Group of jobs that run in parallel |
| **Job** | Basic unit of work with scripts |
| **Runner** | Agent that executes jobs |
| **Artifact** | Files passed between stages |

## Pipeline File

All configuration lives in `.gitlab-ci.yml` at your repo root.

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** GitLab CI/CD is configured entirely through code!

slides.title: Your First Pipeline
slides.content:
# Creating Your First Pipeline ğŸ“

Create `.gitlab-ci.yml` in your repository root:

```yaml
# Define stages (order matters)
stages:
  - build
  - test
  - deploy

# Variables available to all jobs
variables:
  NODE_ENV: production

# Build job
build-job:
  stage: build
  image: node:20
  script:
    - npm ci
    - npm run build
  artifacts:
    paths:
      - dist/
    expire_in: 1 week

# Test job
test-job:
  stage: test
  image: node:20
  script:
    - npm ci
    - npm test
  coverage: '/Coverage: (\d+\.\d+)%/'

# Deploy job
deploy-job:
  stage: deploy
  script:
    - echo "Deploying to server..."
  only:
    - main
```

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Commit this file and watch your pipeline run automatically!

slides.title: Pipeline Configuration Deep Dive
slides.content:
# Advanced Pipeline Configuration âš™ï¸

## Job Keywords

```yaml
my-job:
  # Docker image for this job
  image: python:3.11
  
  # Stage assignment
  stage: test
  
  # Commands to run
  script:
    - pip install -r requirements.txt
    - pytest
  
  # Commands before main script
  before_script:
    - echo "Setting up..."
  
  # Commands after main script
  after_script:
    - echo "Cleaning up..."
  
  # When to run the job
  rules:
    - if: $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == "main"
    - if: $CI_PIPELINE_SOURCE == "merge_request_event"
  
  # Tags for runner selection
  tags:
    - docker
    - linux
  
  # Allow this job to fail
  allow_failure: true
  
  # Retry on failure
  retry:
    max: 2
    when:
      - runner_system_failure
      - stuck_or_timeout_failure
```

## Parallel Jobs with Matrix

```yaml
test:
  stage: test
  parallel:
    matrix:
      - PYTHON_VERSION: ["3.9", "3.10", "3.11"]
        DATABASE: ["postgres", "mysql"]
  image: python:$PYTHON_VERSION
  script:
    - pytest --db $DATABASE
```

# GitLab Runners ğŸƒ

Runners are agents that **execute** your CI/CD jobs.

## Runner Types

| Type | Description | Use Case |
|------|-------------|----------|
| **Shared** | GitLab.com provided | General purpose |
| **Group** | Available to group projects | Team-wide |
| **Project** | Specific to one project | Custom requirements |

## Installing a Runner

```bash
# Download runner
curl -L https://packages.gitlab.com/install/repositories/runner/gitlab-runner/script.deb.sh | sudo bash
sudo apt-get install gitlab-runner

# Register runner

```

## Runner Tags

# Merge Requests (MRs) ğŸ”€

slides.title: Creating Merge Requests
slides.content:
# Creating a Merge Request ğŸ“

## From the Web UI

1. Navigate to your project
2. Click **Merge Requests** â†’ **New merge request**
3. Select source and target branches
4. Fill in the details:
   - Title
   - Description (use templates!)
   - Assignee
   - Reviewer(s)
   - Labels
   - Milestone

## From Command Line

```bash
# Create feature branch
git checkout -b feature/add-authentication

# Make changes and commit
git add .
git commit -m "Add user authentication"

# Push with MR creation
git push -u origin feature/add-authentication \
  -o merge_request.create \
  -o merge_request.target=main \
  -o merge_request.title="Add user authentication" \
  -o merge_request.description="Implements OAuth2 login"
```

## MR Description Template

```markdown
## Summary
Brief description of changes

## Changes Made
- Change 1
- Change 2

## Testing
- [ ] Unit tests added
- [ ] Manual testing completed

## Screenshots (if applicable)

Closes #123
```

slides.title: GitLab Wiki
slides.content:
# GitLab Wiki ğŸ“š

Every GitLab project comes with a built-in **wiki** for documentation.

## Wiki Features

- ğŸ“ **Markdown Support** - Write in familiar syntax
- ğŸ“ **Page Hierarchy** - Organize with folders
- ğŸ” **Search** - Find content quickly
- ğŸ“œ **Version History** - Track all changes
- ğŸ”— **Git Backend** - Clone and edit locally

## Creating Wiki Pages

### Via Web UI
1. Go to **Wiki** in sidebar
2. Click **Create your first page** or **New page**
3. Enter title and content
4. Choose format (Markdown, RDoc, AsciiDoc)
5. Add commit message and save

### Via Git

```bash
# Clone wiki repository
git clone git@gitlab.com:group/project.wiki.git
cd project.wiki

# Create pages
echo "# Home Page" > home.md
echo "# Installation Guide" > installation.md

# Commit and push
git add .
git commit -m "Add wiki pages"
git push origin main
```

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** The wiki has its own git repository, separate from your project!

slides.title: Pipeline Artifacts
slides.content:
# Pipeline Artifacts ğŸ“¦

Artifacts are files created by jobs that can be **passed between stages** or **downloaded**.

## Defining Artifacts

```yaml
build:
  stage: build
  script:
    - npm run build
  artifacts:
    paths:
      - dist/
      - build/
    exclude:
      - dist/**/*.map
    expire_in: 1 week
    name: "build-$CI_COMMIT_SHORT_SHA"

test:
  stage: test
  script:
    - npm test
  artifacts:
    reports:
      junit: test-results.xml
      coverage_report:
        coverage_format: cobertura
        path: coverage/cobertura.xml
    when: always  # Upload even on failure
```

## Artifact Types

| Type | Purpose |
|------|--------|
| `paths` | General files |
| `reports:junit` | Test results |
| `reports:coverage_report` | Code coverage |
| `reports:sast` | Security scan |
| `reports:codequality` | Code quality |

## Downloading Artifacts

- From pipeline page: Click **Download artifacts**
- From job: Click **Browse** or **Download**
- Via API: `GET /projects/:id/jobs/:job_id/artifacts`

> ğŸ¯ **Tip:** Use `dependencies` to control which artifacts are downloaded!

slides.title: Pipeline Variables
slides.content:
# Variables in GitLab CI ğŸ”§

## Variable Types

### Predefined Variables
```yaml
job:
  script:
    - echo $CI_COMMIT_SHA
    - echo $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH
    - echo $CI_PROJECT_NAME
    - echo $CI_PIPELINE_ID
    - echo $CI_JOB_NAME
```

### Custom Variables

```yaml
# Global variables
variables:
  DEPLOYMENT_ENV: production
  API_URL: https://api.example.com

# Job-level variables
job:
  variables:
    LOCAL_VAR: "only in this job"
  script:
    - echo $DEPLOYMENT_ENV
    - echo $LOCAL_VAR
```

### Protected & Masked Variables

Set in **Settings â†’ CI/CD â†’ Variables**:

| Option | Effect |
|--------|--------|
| **Protected** | Only available on protected branches |
| **Masked** | Hidden in job logs |
| **Expand** | Expand variable references |

## Variable Priority (lowest to highest)

1. Predefined variables
2. Project variables
3. Group variables
4. Instance variables
5. Pipeline variables
6. Job variables

> âš ï¸ **Security:** Never commit secrets to `.gitlab-ci.yml`!

slides.title: Pipeline Caching
slides.content:
# Caching in Pipelines âš¡

Caching speeds up jobs by **reusing files** from previous runs.

## Basic Cache Configuration

```yaml
variables:
  npm_config_cache: "$CI_PROJECT_DIR/.npm"

cache:
  key: ${CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG}
  paths:
    - .npm/
    - node_modules/

build:
  script:
    - npm ci --cache .npm
    - npm run build
```

## Cache Strategies

```yaml
job:
  cache:
    key:
      files:
        - package-lock.json  # Key changes when file changes
    paths:
      - node_modules/
    policy: pull-push  # pull, push, or pull-push
```

## Cache vs Artifacts

| Feature | Cache | Artifacts |
|---------|-------|----------|
| Purpose | Speed up jobs | Pass files between jobs |
| Persistence | Between pipelines | Within pipeline |
| Location | Runner-specific | Central storage |
| Reliability | Best-effort | Guaranteed |

## Multiple Caches

```yaml
job:
  cache:
    - key: npm-cache
      paths:
        - node_modules/
    - key: pip-cache
      paths:
        - .pip/
```

slides.title: Environments and Deployments
slides.content:
# Environments & Deployments ğŸš€

GitLab tracks deployments to **environments** like staging and production.

## Defining Environments

```yaml
deploy-staging:
  stage: deploy
  script:
    - ./deploy.sh staging
  environment:
    name: staging
    url: https://staging.example.com
  only:
    - develop

deploy-production:
  stage: deploy
  script:
    - ./deploy.sh production
  environment:
    name: production
    url: https://example.com
  when: manual  # Requires manual trigger
  only:
    - main
```

## Environment Features

- ğŸ“Š **Deployment History** - Track all deployments
- ğŸ”™ **Rollback** - Redeploy previous versions
- ğŸ›‘ **Stop Environment** - Clean up dynamic environments
- ğŸ”— **Environment URL** - Quick access links

## Dynamic Environments

```yaml
review:
  stage: deploy
  script:
    - deploy-review-app.sh
  environment:
    name: review/$CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG
    url: https://$CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG.review.example.com
    on_stop: stop-review
  only:
    - merge_requests

stop-review:
  stage: deploy
  script:
    - delete-review-app.sh
  environment:
    name: review/$CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG
    action: stop
  when: manual
```

slides.title: GitLab Security Features
slides.content:
# Security Scanning ğŸ”’

GitLab includes built-in **security scanning** tools.

## Available Scanners

| Scanner | Purpose |
|---------|--------|
| **SAST** | Static code analysis |
| **DAST** | Dynamic app testing |
| **Container Scanning** | Docker vulnerabilities |
| **Dependency Scanning** | Library vulnerabilities |
| **Secret Detection** | Exposed credentials |
| **License Compliance** | License violations |

## Enabling Security Scans

```yaml
include:
  - template: Security/SAST.gitlab-ci.yml
  - template: Security/Secret-Detection.gitlab-ci.yml
  - template: Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml

stages:
  - build
  - test
  - security
  - deploy
```

## Security Dashboard

- View vulnerabilities across projects
- Track remediation status
- Set severity thresholds
- Create issues from findings

## Merge Request Blocking

```yaml
sast:
  stage: security
  allow_failure: false  # Block MR on failure
```

> ğŸ” **Best Practice:** Run security scans on every merge request!

slides.title: GitLab Container Registry
slides.content:
# Container Registry ğŸ³

GitLab provides a built-in **Docker registry** for every project.

## Using the Registry

```yaml
variables:
  IMAGE_TAG: $CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE:$CI_COMMIT_SHA

build-image:
  stage: build
  image: docker:latest
  services:
    - docker:dind
  before_script:
    - docker login -u $CI_REGISTRY_USER -p $CI_REGISTRY_PASSWORD $CI_REGISTRY
  script:
    - docker build -t $IMAGE_TAG .
    - docker push $IMAGE_TAG

deploy:
  stage: deploy
  script:
    - docker pull $IMAGE_TAG
    - docker run -d $IMAGE_TAG
```

## Registry URLs

```
registry.gitlab.com/group/project
registry.gitlab.com/group/project/image-name
registry.gitlab.com/group/project/image-name:tag
```

## Image Tagging Strategy

```yaml
variables:
  IMAGE_LATEST: $CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE:latest
  IMAGE_SHA: $CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE:$CI_COMMIT_SHORT_SHA
  IMAGE_TAG: $CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE:$CI_COMMIT_TAG

script:
  - docker build -t $IMAGE_SHA -t $IMAGE_LATEST .
  - docker push $IMAGE_SHA
  - docker push $IMAGE_LATEST
```

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Use commit SHA tags for immutable references!
